dsls.markdown: # Welcome! ##### Welcome to Code.org's self-paced online course Teaching Computer Science Fundamentals! ##### This course is designed for educators who want to teach K-5 Computer Science Fundamentals courses. After completing this online module, you'll be ready to teach one or more of Code.org's Computer Science Fundamentals courses in your classroom. ## Take the pre-survey ##### Code.org values and is responsive to feedback. Please fill out this short pre-survey to reflect on your goals for this online course and to tell us about who you are and how we can best support you. Take the pre-survey

# Introduction ## Go at your own pace ##### Suggested times are given for each part and lesson. However, we encourage you to engage with the content at your own pace. ## Find help when you need it ##### If you need help with this online course, visit support.code.org and our community forums. You'll likely find the answer to your question there. If you still need additional support, email support@code.org and a Code.org staff member will get back to you as soon as they can. Consider going through this online module with a partner or group of colleagues! ## Find the learning experience that works for you ##### We recognize online learning is not for everyone. If you find yourself needing more one-on-one attention or know you learn better in a facilitator-led workshop where there is opportunity for collaboration and engagement with others, consider participating in one of our in-person professional development opportunities. ## About this module ##### This online module is made up of three parts: * ##### **Part I: Teaching Computer Science** introduces you to computer science teaching practices. * ##### Click "Continue" to begin Part I. * ##### **Part II: Concepts in Courses A - F**, takes you through videos, lesson levels, and resources students will use to learn about computer science concepts. * Click here to begin Part II. * ##### **Part III: Next Steps**, guides you in identifying next steps after this course to learn more about computer science. * Click here to begin Part III.

https://studio.code.org/s/k5-onlinepd-20.long_instructions: ##### This video features Code.org's founder and CEO, Hadi Partovi, in welcoming you to Code.org's Professional Learning.

dsls.markdown: # What is Code.org? ## Code.org's Vision ##### **"Every student in every school has the opportunity to learn computer science as part of their core K-12 education."** ##### Code.org is part of a larger computer science community working towards equity in CS and collaborates with other equity-minded computer science organizations such as Microsoft, National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT), CSforAll, and the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA). *** ##### **“Computing and technology hold the promise of solving problems big and small and shaping the world around us. But if the people who work in computing related jobs don't represent our communities and our populations, the solutions they develop won't be representative either.”** - Guide to inclusive CS education, 2019

# What is Computer Science?

##### The Computer Science Teacher Association (CSTA) defines computer science as, “The study of computers and **algorithmic processes**, including their principles, their **hardware and software designs**, their implementation, and their **impact on society**.”

* ##### **Algorithms** or step-by-step processes to complete a task like brushing your teeth, playing a game, or opening a file on a computer.

* ##### **Hardware** such as a mouse, keyboard, or monitor.
   
* ##### **Software** such as Android, Microsoft Windows, or internet browsers like Google Chrome.

* ##### **Design and use** of hardware and software and their effect on us and others.  
	* For example apps for social change, artificial intelligence, or colors displayed on a monitor.

### Computer science is also about creativity, problem solving, and using code as a tool.

# What is Computer Science Fundamentals? ##### Computer Science Fundamentals are courses for elementary students in grades K-5 that ***build and strengthen*** computer science knowledge and skills. ##### **Does not require you or your students to have any prior knowledge or skills in computer science.** ## Why teach Computer Science Fundamentals? * ##### Supports both pre-readers and readers. * ##### Aligned to K12 Computer Science Framework practices and CSTA K-12 standards. * ##### Includes cross-curricular activities mapped to ELA/Math Common Core State Standards and Next Generation Science Standards. ## Why does computer science matter? ##### Watch this video and learn more about why Computer Science Matters. ***

dsls.markdown: # Key Strategies ##### Consider the following strategies as you plan and prepare to create positive learning computer science experiences for your students. ## Role of the Teacher * ##### Decide when you will guide students and when students will guide each other. * ##### Model debugging for students with think-alouds to share your problem solving process. ## Discovery and Inquiry * ##### Encourage student-led exploration of concepts to help students build their own understanding. ## Classroom Community * ##### Set a culture of learning from peers and welcoming mistakes as part of the learning process.

# Debugging

##### Debugging and pair programming are built-in computer science teaching and learning strategies.

## Debugging

##### **Bug:** Something that is going wrong with the code. An error.
##### **Debugging:** To find and fix errors.

##### Debugging is an essential skill students develop individually when working through lesson levels.

##### Debugging is also a process students can engage in as a whole group to practice problem solving, collaboration, and communication.

# Pair Programming ##### Pair programming is a technique in which two programmers work together at one computer. * ##### The “navigator” tells the “driver” what to type or write. * ##### The “driver” types or writes the code. * ##### The two programmers switch roles often. ##### For information about setting up pair programming, check out this support article, How does pair programming on Code.org work?

# Journaling ##### All lessons in CS Fundamentals include reflection prompts for students to answer questions and write down thoughts about a lesson in a journal. Journals are also helpful as scratch paper for building programs, debugging, and strategizing. ## Implementing journaling * ##### Encourage students to keep their journals beside them at all times when coding. * ##### Have students copy down answers to puzzles that they might need in future levels. * ##### Ask students to draw or describe emotions at the top of the pages to identify their feelings about concepts. * ##### End each lesson with a question that helps students reflect on their learning.

# Part II: Concepts in Courses A - F ## Welcome to Part II: Concepts in Courses A - F! ##### Part II of this online course focuses on the computer science concepts and skills students will learn in courses A - F. ##### In each lesson of Part II you will find the following:
Online Course Lesson Objectives ##### The objectives listed in this section are intended for you as the educator preparing to teach Computer Science Fundamentals courses, rather than as objectives for students in Computer Science Fundamentals lessons. Objectives for students are found in lesson plans.
Computer Science Concepts ##### "Computer Science Concepts" include key vocabulary and definitions about the computer science concepts students will be learning throughout Computer Science Fundamentals courses. ##### The "Computer Science Concepts" section includes one or more of the following tasks for you to complete: * ##### reading a lesson plan and previewing the teacher slide deck that accompanies the lesson. * ##### watching a "Lesson in Action" video in which a teacher demonstrates a lesson to students. * ##### watching the same video that introduces a computer science concept to your students.
Learning Tools ##### The "Learning Tools" section identifies which learning tools students will engage with during lessons. * ##### **Maze/Collector Puzzles (all courses):** Students move a character across an 8x8 square grid to perform actions such as collecting objects. * ##### **The Artist (all courses):** Students program the Artist character to create drawings and require persistence to sometimes re-create an image. Free play levels with the Artist allow students to get creative and draw whatever they want. * ##### **Play Lab (Courses A - C):** Students create their own stories and simple games using Play Lab. Characters can speak, move, and even express emotions. Play Lab projects are interactive and controlled by the user's keyboard and mouse. * ##### **Sprite Lab (Courses E - F):** Students create fun animations with Sprite Lab such as interactive posters, games, and simulations.
Concepts Reiterated Across Courses ##### The "Concepts reiterated across courses" section provides you with a cross-section of student lesson levels that represent how a computer science concept unfolds and is reiterated within either a single course or across multiple courses. The goal of this section is to provide you with the big picture of how students learn computer science concepts and develop skills over time with Computer Science Fundamentals courses.

# Part II: Concepts in Courses A - F ##### Below is a list of the lessons included in Part II: Concepts in Courses A - F. ##### We suggest planning 20 - 25 minutes to complete each lesson in Part II. However, feel free to start and stop at your own pace and take more or less time as needed. * ##### Suggested total time for a ***single*** course: 3 - 4 hours * ##### Suggested total time for ***all*** courses: 6 - 8 hours *** ## Navigating Lessons in Part II ##### You can go through lessons in Part II using one of two options: * ##### **Option A** is best if you are limited on time and definitely know which course you will teach. * ##### **Option B** is best if you are not limited on time, teach multiple grades, or do not know which course you will teach. ## Option A ##### Use the table below to know which lessons and computer science concepts are part of the course you plan to teach. ##### For example, if you plan on teaching Course E, then begin by clicking on Lesson 5: Sequencing with Sprites listed in the table and continue on with Lessons 6, 8, 9, and 11.

# Review:  Sequencing

## Prompt

##### Pair Programming is first introduced to students when they learn about sequencing in Courses A and B.  How can pair programming help students learn about sequencing and algorithms?

* * *

## Vocabulary

**Pair programming** is a technique in which two programmers work together at one computer.  The "driver" writes code while the "navigator" directs the design and setup of the code.  The two programmers switch roles often.  

**Sequencing** describes the process of ordering steps in a linear manner.

**Algorithms** are lists of steps to complete a task. Programs are algorithms written as code for a computer to execute.

# Introduction to Sequencing with Sprites ## Course Lesson Objective ##### After completing Lesson 5 you will be able to: * ##### define sprite and sprite behavior. * ##### add a sprite to the screen. * ##### change a sprite's behavior. ## CS Concepts ##### A **sprite** is a graphic character on the screen with properties that describe its location, movement, and look. ##### A **behavior** is an action that a sprite performs continuously until it's told to stop. *** ### **Task: Read a lesson plan** * ##### Read the **skill building** lesson plan, Course E - Lesson 3: Swimming Fish with Sprite Lab from Course E that first introduces students to sprites. * ##### Also, preview the teacher slides that accompany Course E - Lesson 3: Swimming Fish with Sprite Lab.

# Introduction to Sequencing with Sprites

## Learning Tools 

##### Students in Courses E and F engage with Sprite Lab to practice coding sprites with algorithms, loops, and conditionals.

## Concepts reiterated across Courses E and F

##### **Course E** introduces what a sprite is and how to code the behavior of sprites. 

##### **Course F** also introduces students to sprites to support those students who may not have engaged with Course E. Course F focuses on how apps and tools give users choices about how to use sprites.

This lesson contains a **mini-project** called _Swimming Fish_. This progression may feel very different from what has come earlier in the course for you as well as your students. These levels have some new characteristics you may want to explore before starting. 

-   The code your students write in one level will automatically transfer over to the other levels. This allows them to build gradually and iterate on their ideas as they learn.
-   These levels allow for more open-ended creativity. Empower your students to determine for themselves when they have completed each task. There is no one right answer! 
-   Example solutions are available for this step of the progression which can be viewed by opening the teacher panel to the right.

This level will validate a student’s code by checking that the following conditions have been met:

-   Student must have at least one fish sprite with an active behavior.

courseF_events_ship_2023.short_instructions: Use an event to make the ship begin moving forward after 8 seconds.
courseF_events_ship_2023.long_instructions:
#Blast Off!
![expandable](https://images.code.org/6a56375157dd2aabfb255e29cd717cbc-image-1611082032886.2021-01-19 13_46_53.gif)
This ship is ready to go! Use an "seconds"8 event to make the ship begin moving forward after 8 seconds. ## Do This * Add an `at 8 seconds` event block to your workspace. * Connect a `sprite begins` block under this event. * Give the sprite a behavior to make it "blast off" (move right) across the screen after 8 seconds.

# Do a Barrel Roll!
![expandable](https://images.code.org/08b3e8a6ed02260555675174a0a41c13-image-1611354854787.2021-01-22 17_33_41.gif)
Let's make the plane sprite spin left when you press one key, and right when you press the other key. Do you remember this block? "creature_18_1" ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and press both arrows to see what happens.
What's the bug?When you press the first arrow key, the plane spins, but the program stops working when you press the second arrow key.
* Add an `sprite stops` block under each event. * Use this block to stop the opposite behavior. *The sprite should now spin in either direction when you press each arrow key.*

courseF_events_choice_conflict2_2023.short_instructions: Make the sprite shrink when you press one key, and grow when you press the other key.
courseF_events_choice_conflict2_2023.long_instructions:
# Shrink and Grow
![expandable](https://images.code.org/ee8148a40007249560471e6a99b537e3-image-1611697250512.2021-01-26 16_38_41.gif)
Let's make the sprite shrink when you press one key, and grow when you press the other key. Do you remember this block? "creature_05_1" ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and press both arrows to see what happens.
What's the bug?When you press an arrow key, the sprite begins one behavior. When you press the second arrow key, the sprite seems to stop responding.
* Add an `sprite stops` block under each event. * Use this block to stop the opposite behavior. *The sprite should now shrink or grow when you press each arrow key.*

courseF_events_choice_pufferfish_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the pufferfish quickly expand in size! Practice using events.
courseF_events_choice_pufferfish_2023.short_instructions: Use the "while key pressed" event block to repeatedly change the sprite's size while the user presses a key.
courseF_events_choice_pufferfish_2023.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
![expandable](https://images.code.org/ecd2788bd12f594a846de079ed22f484-image-1611328367728.2021-01-22 10_12_02.gif)
The when/while??? block has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. Use the `when/while key pressed` event block to repeatedly change the sprite's *size* while the user presses a key. ## Do This * Add a `key pressed` event to your workspace. Set it to either "when" or while". * Connect a `change size by` **action** block under this event. * Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run. *Extra Challenge:* Make the sprite get bigger when you press "up" and smaller when you press "down".

courseF_events_choice_penguin_2023.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
![expandable](https://images.code.org/a81a5d5487327d7783540239d87a988e-image-1611351171916.2021-01-22 16_31_44.gif)
The when/while??? has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. The `when key pressed` event block makes the sprite move with the keys, but it feels slow and clunky. ## Do This * Run the program and press the arrow keys to see how the sprite moves. * Change each `when key pressed` block to `while key pressed` to make the sprite's movement faster and smoother.

This lesson contains a **mini-project** called _Sticker Design_. This progression may feel very different from what has come earlier in the course for you as well as your students. These levels have some new characteristics you may want to explore before starting. 

-   The code your students write in one level will automatically transfer over to the other levels. This allows them to build gradually and iterate on their ideas as they learn.
-   These levels are **not checked for correctness** to allow for more open-ended creativity. Empower your students to determine for themselves when they have completed each task. There is no one right answer! 
-   Example solutions are available for this step of the progression which can be viewed by opening the teacher panel to the right.

This lesson contains a **mini-project**. This progression may feel very different from what has come earlier in the course for you as well as your students. These levels have some new characteristics you may want to explore before starting. 

-   The code your students write in one level will automatically transfer over to the other levels. This allows them to build gradually and iterate on their ideas as they learn.
-   These levels allow for more open-ended creativity. Empower your students to determine for themselves when they have completed each task. There is no one right answer! 
-   Example solutions are available for this step of the progression which can be viewed by opening the teacher panel to the right.

## Code Blocks

##### **If block:**The code inside a conditional block runs if a condition is true.

[][0]

##### **If/else block:** The code inside a conditional block runs if a condition is true, otherwise if the condition is false other code is run.

# Review:  Variables

## Prompt

* * *

## Definitions

dsls.markdown: # Part III: Next Steps ## Come to a professional learning workshop Check out our professional learning map to see the Computer Science Fundamentals workshops that are being offered in your area. ## Get connected - **Check out @teachcode on Twitter.** - **Join the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA):** The CSTA is an engaged community of educators across the nation that is committed to bringing computer science education to their students while raising awareness of the subject to the general public. They host an annual conference and also have chapters that hold local meetings. ## Find help and community - ##### **Find computer science guest speakers**: Find passionate and engaging tech industry professionals who would love to talk to your class about their jobs. - ##### **Check out the teacher forum**: Ask questions, check out great teacher-created resources, and connect with other teachers on the forum. - ##### **Get support**: Access support.code.org, where you can post questions, respond to other teacher's posts, and read FAQs by Code.org staff. On this page, you'll also be able to directly contact Code.org with any questions you may have. * ##### Access support.code.org and our teacher forum via the dropdown menu on the top right of the Code.org homepage.

# Part III: Next Steps ## Take the post-survey ##### Regardless of how much of this course you completed, we want to hear your feedback. Please submit this short survey to help us improve the course going forward! Take the post-survey ## Print a certificate ##### Congratulations on completing this professional development online course. Provided you have completed all levels in this training, you can download and print a certificate of accomplishment now by completing the following steps: - Click here to create your certificate. - ##### Enter your name into the input field/box. - ##### Click Print Certificates. - ##### Right click on the image of the certificate and choose "Save Image As..." to download to your computer. ## Thank you for your participation!
